Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Fatigue and weakness for the past three months.

Present Illness.Onset: The patient noticed onset of fatigue and general weakness three months ago, with no specific event triggering the symptoms.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Fatigue and weakness, progressively worsening. Shortness of breath on exertion and pallor noted. Symptoms are worse in the morning and improve slightly with rest.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Dizziness, headaches, pale skin, and abdominal bloating. The patient's partner reports snoring and observed occasional breath-holds during sleep.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Patient sought consultation with her primary care physician one month ago and laboratory tests revealed anemia. Prescribed iron supplements which did not improve symptoms.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Patient reports poor sleep quality, reduced appetite, and a sensation of abdominal fullness. No significant weight changes.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally healthy until the onset of the current symptoms.
Past History.Infectious Disease History: No history of significant infectious diseases.
Past History.Immunization History: Up to date with all vaccinations.

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, occasional alcohol consumption, balanced diet.
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: High school teacher, sedentary job with moderate stress levels.
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to toxins, dust, or radioactive substances.
Personal History.Travel History: Travelled to Europe 5 years ago, no recent travel.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father deceased (Heart disease at 70), mother alive (healthy at 68), no siblings.

Systematic Examination.Head and Organs: Normocephalic, no abnormalities noted on ENT examination.
Systematic Examination.Neck: No thyromegaly, no jugular venous distention.
Systematic Examination.Chest: Clear lung fields, no wheezes or rhonchi. Regular heart sounds, no murmurs.
Systematic Examination.Abdomen: Mild hepatosplenomegaly, no tenderness, bowel sounds present.
Systematic Examination.Limbs: No edema, normal range of motion.
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert and oriented, cranial nerves intact, normal motor and sensory function.

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Hematology: Signs of anemia, possible splenomegaly.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: CBC: Hemoglobin 8 g/dL, MCV 65 fL, MCH 20 pg. Peripheral smear: Microcytic hypochromic anemia. Serum iron study: Elevated ferritin, low TIBC. Hemoglobin electrophoresis confirms elevated HbA2, consistent with thalassemia.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: History of anemia not responsive to iron supplements, physical signs of pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, laboratory findings indicative of thalassemia.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Iron deficiency anemia, ruled out by serum iron studies. Megaloblastic anemia, ruled out by normal B12 and folate levels. Neonatal jaundice, not applicable given patient's age.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted with symptoms of anemia and confirmed diagnosis of thalassemia. Plan to monitor hemoglobin levels, provide supportive care with folate supplements, and consider blood transfusion if hemoglobin drops further.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Patient remains stable, hemoglobin monitored daily, folate supplements initiated.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Discussed case with attending hematologist, consensus on current management plan.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient remains stable, continue current supportive treatment.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient has responded well to supportive treatment, stable hemoglobin levels, no need for immediate transfusion.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Hematology consulted, agree with ongoing management plan.

Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Blood transfusion if hemoglobin falls below 7 g/dL

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: CBC, Peripheral Smear, Serum Iron Studies, Hemoglobin Electrophoresis
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Normal temperature, stable pulse and respiration rates, blood pressure within normal range.

Diseases of the Blood and Blood-Forming.Name: Thalassemia
Diseases of the Blood and Blood-Forming.Symptoms: Anemia, decreased physical strength, iron deposition in organs, changes in skull shape, hepatosplenomegaly, protruding abdomen
Diseases of the Blood and Blood-Forming.Differential Diagnosis: Iron deficiency anemia, megaloblastic anemia, neonatal jaundice.
